summary: This Privy Council appeal, decided on 19th July 1937, arose from a West African Court of Appeal judgment that set aside a 1931 land conveyance from Mrs. Johnson, an 82-year-old widow, to her physician, Dr. Johnson. The conveyance, nominally for £1,500, was deemed a voluntary gift. The trial judge, Webber C.J., dismissed the claim, finding no undue influence and that the gift reflected Mrs. Johnson’s free will. The Court of Appeal reversed, holding that a confidential doctor-patient relationship existed and the presumption of undue influence was not rebutted. The Privy Council upheld the Court of Appeal, ruling that the relationship was sufficiently fiduciary to trigger the presumption and that the defendant failed to prove the gift was made with independent, informed consent, despite some evidence of the donor’s capacity and preference for the conveyance form.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; decision of the West African Court of Appeal upheld

jurisdiction.country: United Kingdom (on appeal from West Africa)

caseType: Civil Appeal (Undue Influence in Property Conveyance)
citations: Inche Noriah v. Shaik Allie Bin Omar [1929] A.C. 127
Colonial Securities Trust Company v. Massey [1896] 1 Q.B. 38
rationaleHighlights: A doctor-patient relationship, especially involving prolonged care, can create a presumption of undue influence.
The burden lies on the donee to prove the gift was a free and independent act of the donor.
Independent legal advice must be informed and comprehensive to rebut the presumption.

The availability of both donor and donee as live witnesses strengthened the trial judge’s ability to assess credibility, but the Privy Council found the evidence insufficient to rebut the presumption.
Preference for a conveyance over a will or gift deed, while relevant, does not alone prove independence from influence.
